papers.title: Neighborhood Isolation and Mortgage Redlining in Milwaukee County
keyFindings: Statistically significant differences in home ownership rates among HOLC grades (p = 0.000) and median household income (p = 0.038) persist through 2010.
Home ownership rate for Grade A increased more than 10% over 1970-2010, while rates for Grades B, C, and D did not change.
Home values, ownership rates, and incomes in non-redlined areas (A/B/C) were continuously higher than redlined areas (D) across all four time points: 1950, 1970, 1990, and 2010.
The gap between Grade A and Grade D neighborhoods widened over time, not narrowed, despite civil rights legislation.
Redlined neighborhoods appear as 'social islands' — areas with low home ownership creating extreme isolation.

The Federal Fair Housing Act (1968) and Equal Credit Opportunity Act (1974) did not completely remedy the effects of historic housing discrimination. Socioeconomic conditions in redlined neighborhoods became more isolated in recent years.

quotes.text: The fourth grade or D areas are characterized by detrimental influences in a pronounced degree, undesirable population or an infiltration of it. Low percentage of home ownership, very poor maintenance and often vandalism prevail.

Our results suggest that the Federal Fair Housing Act (1968) and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (1974) did not completely remedy the effects of historic housing discrimination. In fact, the socioeconomic conditions of the redlined neighborhoods in Milwaukee County became more isolated from the rest of the city in recent years.

papers.title: The Legacy of Structural Racism: Associations Between Historic Redlining, Current Mortgage Lending, and Health
papers.authors: Emily E. Lynch, Lorraine Halinka Malcoe, Sarah E. Laurent, Jason Richardson, Bruce C. Mitchell, Helen C.S. Meier
keyFindings: 73% higher odds of current lending discrimination for every one-unit increase in historic redlining score (OR = 1.73, 95% CI: 1.16, 2.58).
Predicted probability of current lending discrimination: 64.40% for tracts with high historic redlining vs. 25.80% for tracts with low historic redlining.
Historic redlining associated with increased poor physical health prevalence (β = 1.34) and poor mental health prevalence (β = 1.26).
Neighborhoods with high sustained disinvestment had far worse physical health (β = 5.33) and mental health (β = 4.32) than high-investment neighborhoods.
Infant mortality was highest in 'disinvested' neighborhoods (β = 5.87) — predominantly Black neighborhoods on the northwest side.
Milwaukee ranked consistently worst or near-worst among the 50 largest U.S. metro areas across 30 indicators of racial inequality.
Tracts with high historic redlining: average poverty rate of 28.23% vs. 15.59% for low redlining tracts.
Tracts with current lending discrimination: only 11.78 originated loans per 1000 family homes vs. 31.93 for tracts without.
Infant mortality rate among non-Hispanic Blacks was three times higher than non-Hispanic whites in Milwaukee.

quotes.text: Milwaukee, in many ways, has emerged as the epitome of a 21st century racial regime: a metropolis of entrenched segregation and racial inequality.
Structural racism, as manifested in historic and current forms of lending disinvestment, predicts poor health in Milwaukee's hypersegregated neighborhoods.
Neighborhoods today are a manifestation of a myriad of racist housing policies and practices that have fundamentally shaped housing tenure, the built environment, and health.

In a mortgage system with fixed costs and dynamic profits, lenders are deterred from lending in communities of color that have lower incomes, smaller houses, and are located in areas with less demand. If mortgages are not being made, the value of homes and businesses are negatively impacted, depressing the wealth of the entire community.

papers.title: Milwaukee's History of Segregation and Development: A Biography of Four Neighborhoods
papers.authors: Jessie Paulson, Meghan Wierschke & Gabe Jun Ha Kim
keyFindings: Milwaukee is the most highly segregated city in the United States.
The I-43 highway destroyed Bronzeville's commercial district on Walnut Street and displaced thousands of African American residents.
Displaced minority families moved shorter distances than white families: 0.95 miles vs. 1.25 miles during I-43 displacement.
Population density in northern Milwaukee (Bronzeville area) dropped from 24,430 people per square mile in 1940 to 8,300 in 2010.
Between 1960 and 2000, the City of Milwaukee lost 150,000 people — the size of Green Bay.
Peak of Black employment in Milwaukee was in 1976, then tapered off following deindustrialization.
Suburban communities (Wauwatosa, Waukesha) deliberately resisted African American employment and residence, including refusing to build bus or rail connections.
One vacant house reduces every other property on the block by $7,000.
The Realtor Code of Ethics (1928-1955) explicitly directed realtors not to introduce 'members of any race or nationality' into neighborhoods.
Modern insurance redlining continues: 'high-crime area' designations map onto the same areas as HOLC D-grades.

quotes.text: Restrictive covenants and redlining set the city on a segregated track that is incredibly difficult to break.
quotes.source: Rep. Evan Goyke (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: Housing discrimination is not as blatantly obvious as it was in the days of redlining, they use hidden codes to screen tenants as means of discrimination.
quotes.source: Rep. Evan Goyke (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: There is not a single bullet... It's a product of generation and it'll take just as long, if not longer, to get rid of.
quotes.source: Rep. Evan Goyke (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: Interstates were routed right down to the African American communities. Tore at the fabric of the community.
quotes.source: Paul Geenen (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: Light rail was opposed each time. Kept saying 'they'll be coming out here' which created the subtle pressure that keeps the African American community in the city.
quotes.source: Paul Geenen (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: Persistent impacts of redlining lead to continued educational segregation, overexposure to the police (high incarceration rates), and unequal education systems.
quotes.source: Professor Moore (quoted in Paulson et al.)

quotes.text: A Realtor should never be instrumental in introducing into a neighborhood a character of property or occupancy, members of any race or nationality, or any individuals whose presence will clearly be detrimental to property values in that neighborhood.
quotes.source: National Association of Real Estate Boards, Article 34, 1928

neighborhoods.southSide: Settled by Polish immigrants in the late 1800s; transitioned to Latino population. Little evidence of redlining between Latinos and Polish due to shared Catholic Church ties. Self-segregation through ethnic enclaving rather than forced segregation.
neighborhoods.bronzeville: Historically Black 12-block area where nearly 21,000 African Americans settled between 1900-1950. Destroyed by I-43 highway construction in the 1950s-60s. Walnut Street was Milwaukee's Black business district. The community expanded by the 'Three-Block Rule' — new churches could not be within three blocks of another, so the community grew in increments.
neighborhoods.riverwest: Formed as a community by the East Side Housing Action Coalition in the 1970s. Successfully fought the city's 'faltering' designation. Changed from 95-100% white in 1940 to about 75% white in 2010.
neighborhoods.thirdWard: Went through four identities: Irish settlers, Italian industrialists, deindustrialization/decay, and gentrification. The 1892 fire destroyed over 400 buildings. I-794 destroyed remaining houses. Now a gentrified shopping/dining destination.

papers.title: An Improvised World: Jazz and Community in Milwaukee, 1950-1970
keyFindings: Jazz clubs were direct casualties of I-43 highway construction — Jimmy Mack's Main Event relocated twice before closing in 2002.
African American migration, urban renewal, and deindustrialization combined to push jazz out of the Black community.
The jazz community survived but became smaller, middle class, and predominantly white.
Jazz served as a cultural bridge between Black and white communities, but urban renewal disrupted this potential.

quotes.text: That was where the Black Jazz, the Black musicians, and the Black audience hung out.
The African American community in Milwaukee was in a constant state of reappraisal, adjustment, and ultimately improvisational living.

papers.title: Urban Renewal and the Development of Milwaukee's African American Community: 1960-1980
keyFindings: I-43 highway destroyed Bronzeville, pushing displaced residents into Garfield Park (renamed Harambee).
Black male employment in Milwaukee dropped from 73.4% (1970) to 44.7% (2010).
Model Cities area lost 3,371 net housing units between 1966 and 1971.
12.8% of working-age Black men in Wisconsin were incarcerated in 2010 — twice the national average.
African Americans organized community-driven renewal in Harambee — 'the quintessential example' of Black agency in urban renewal.
Infant mortality rate for African Americans: 15.6 per 1,000 births vs. 6.4 for whites.

quotes.text: Urban renewal resulted in the wholesale destruction of black neighborhoods, wiping away important areas of residential, economic and cultural development.

papers.title: The Unworkable Program: Urban Renewal in Kilbourntown-3 and Midtown, Milwaukee
keyFindings: Milwaukee used federal urban renewal funds to continue racist policies of neighborhood segregation and containment.
K-3 (predominantly African American) was cleared as a 'slum'; adjacent Midtown (white) was 'conserved' — same federal program, opposite outcomes by race.
Class IV Areas (D-grade HOLC zones) were designated for 'substantial clearance and redevelopment' in the 1960s — the grades became a demolition blueprint.
More homes were destroyed than rebuilt. The city subverted federal requirements for adequate relocation and citizen participation.

quotes.text: The continuation of white neighborhood resistance, racist real estate practices, and federal redlining of minority neighborhoods assured that slums would continue to be created.

papers.title: Milwaukee African Americans: A Community Portrait
keyFindings: Walnut Street was Milwaukee's Black business district with dozens of Black-owned establishments.
Nearly 21,000 African Americans settled in Milwaukee's Bronzeville between 1900-1950.
The Malcolm M. King family exemplified the professional class that built Bronzeville's institutions.
Jazz clubs, billiard halls, dry goods stores, and law offices lined Walnut Street.

papers.title: Milwaukee History Maps: Research Synthesis for Bronzeville Center for the Arts
keyFindings: Mapped timelines of Milwaukee's Black commercial and cultural development from 1900 to present.
Spatial overview organized into political, cultural, infrastructural, and industrial categories.
Documents the geographic concentration and dispersal of Black community institutions over time.

papers.title: Black Heritage in Milwaukee
keyFindings: Visual documentation of Black community infrastructure, institutions, and neighborhoods in Milwaukee.
Historical photographs and records of buildings and community spaces that were later demolished.

crossPaperThemes.theme: The 1938 map still predicts outcomes today
crossPaperThemes.summary: All three papers confirm that HOLC grades from 1938 remain predictive of economic outcomes, health outcomes, and neighborhood character over 80+ years later.

crossPaperThemes.theme: The gap is widening, not closing
crossPaperThemes.summary: Chang & Smith show isolation increasing over time. Lynch et al. show Milwaukee's Black communities are worse off than 40-50 years ago. Fair housing legislation did not remedy the structural damage.

Redlining was compounded by highway destruction (I-43 through Bronzeville), blockbusting, suburban exclusion of transit, and modern insurance redlining. These are not independent forces but reinforcing systems.

crossPaperThemes.theme: Health is shaped by housing policy
crossPaperThemes.summary: Neighborhoods with sustained disinvestment have dramatically worse physical health, mental health, and infant mortality. The association between redlining and health is mediated 85-87% by current socioeconomic conditions created by decades of disinvestment.

crossPaperThemes.theme: Bronzeville: From thriving community to demolished landscape
crossPaperThemes.summary: Six studies document the arc of Bronzeville — from a vibrant 12-block community with jazz clubs and Black-owned businesses, through I-43 highway destruction and urban renewal clearance, to the emergence of Harambee as a community-driven alternative.
